THE SUPREME COURT OF APPEAL OF SOUTH AFRICA
CASE NUMBER: 181/96
In the matter between:
Stanley Voegt
First Appellant
Winston Maholwana
Second Appellant
and
The State
Respondent
CORAM: HOWIE, HARMS and ZULMAN JJA
Date of Hearing: 23 February 1998 Date of Judgment: 16 March 1998
JUDGMENT
2 ZULMAN JA
The appellants were charged with two other accused in the Cape of Good Hope Provincial Division with the murder of one Harold Eksteen,
the possession of unlicensed firearms, and the possession of ammunition without a licence. The appellants were convicted on all of
the charges. The other two accused were acquitted. The appellants were sentenced to life imprisonment on the murder count and to
two years on each of the counts relating to the possession of firearms and ammunition. The appellants appeal, with leave, to this
Court, both against their convictions and sentences.

sections.facts: The appellants, Stanley Voegt and Winston Maholwana, together with two other accused, were tried in the Cape of Good Hope Provincial Division for the murder of Harold Eksteen as well as for the unlawful possession of unlicensed firearms and ammunition. The trial court convicted the appellants on all counts, sentencing them to life imprisonment for murder and two years for each firearms‑related charge. The two co‑accused were acquitted.
sections.issues: The appeal raised two main issues: (1) whether the convictions for murder and for possession of firearms and ammunition were legally sound; and (2) whether the sentences imposed were appropriate under the relevant statutory framework.
sections.principles: The court considered the statutory provisions governing murder, the requirements for proving unlawful possession of firearms and ammunition, and the sentencing guidelines applicable to life imprisonment and fixed‑term sentences for weapon offences. Precedent on the burden of proof for murder and the discretion of sentencing courts was applied.
sections.application: Applying these principles, the court examined the evidence presented at trial, assessed whether the conviction for murder satisfied the requisite mens rea and actus reus, and evaluated the proportionality of the sentences in light of the seriousness of the offences and the appellants' criminal histories.
sections.conclusion: The court dismissed the appeal, affirming both the convictions and the sentences imposed on the appellants.
